Award.AwardTitle: SEES Fellows: Development of Luminescent Solar Collectors for spectral selective energy harvesting in agricultural and biofuel production
Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary project seeks to develop solar windows consisting of semitransparent Luminescent Solar Concentrators (LSC) with optimized efficiency for the utilization of electrical, chemical and thermal solar energy. The LSC design includes the use of organic or quantum dot dyes that absorb the solar spectrum with high efficiency and minimal self-absorption while passing wavelengths needed for plant growth. Optimization of the LSC cells and incorporation into a small greenhouse structure will be performed in order to monitor reliability and power generation during one year of exposure in outdoor testing conditions. The robustness of the LSC greenhouse to a variety of weather conditions, shading, and 20-year lifetimes under accelerated conditions will be evaluated. The impact of the window-integrated LSC technology on plant growth and water retention will be studied. Separately, studies on algae response to wavelength specific lighting will be used to design an LSC optimized for algal growth, and that LSC will be tested for its energy harvesting capability and algae growth enhancement on site where algae is being grown for bio-fuel production.

In addition to the research, this project will establish ?EarthReach,? a program of public outreach and engagement of undergraduate and graduate students in teaching junior high and high school students about environmental sustainability.

Building-integrated photovoltaics offer a large market opportunity for solar power installations since the cost of the building can be used to offset the cost of the integrated solar panels. The goal of this project is to accelerate deployment of photovoltaics through the research and development of solar windows that can produce energy at a competitive cost, are robust to outdoor weather and shading conditions, and meet 20-year accelerated lifetimes. This technology can then be tailored to meet demands of agriculture, building integration, and larger scale power plants. This would reduce carbon emissions by achieving cost parity of renewable generated power with fossil fuel-based power and provide a technology platform for CO2 capture that benefits the agriculture community.

This project is supported under the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows) program, with the goal of helping to enable discoveries needed to inform actions that lead to environmental, energy and societal sustainability while creating the necessary workforce to address these challenges. With SEES Fellows support, this project will enable a promising early career researcher to establish themselves in an independent research career related to sustainability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome Report: SEES Fellows: Development of Luminescent Solar Collectors for spectral selective energy harvesting in agricultural and biofuel production


Luminescent Solar Collector (LSC) technology was developed and optimized for use in solar power generating windows to be integrated into greenhouses directly above crop production. Additionally, this project created Women In Science and Engineering (WiSE) Outreach at UC Santa Cruz to bring diverse groups of undergrad and graduate student STEM researchers into K-12 classrooms, as well as facilitated the successful collaboration of a cross-disciplinary group of scientists and students in Physics, Plant Physiology, Environmental Sciences at UC Santa Cruz and Microbiology at NASA Ames.

An LSC consists of PV cells attached to a waveguide, such as a sheet of glass, incorporating a luminescent material to absorb light and emit it so that a portion of that light is concentrated onto the PV cells to enhance the power. For the greenhouse application, a dye was chosen to absorb green wavelengths of light that plants don’t use efficiently and convert them to red wavelengths of light with high photosynthetic efficiency. The innovative front-facing LSC window was optimized in various design parameters in order to enhance the panel efficiency.1,2  The leading design was selected to build full size LSC window roof panels (2’ x 3’) to construct a 500 W off-grid power-generating greenhouse and control greenhouse that were used for power generation and reliability field-testing data collection over the course of a year.3

After the successful completion of this first plant trial, the greenhouse solar panels were trialed in various commercial and research greenhouses to test the effect of the light spectrum on vegetables, algae, berries, cut flowers, and ornamentals.4,5 Collaborators in the plant trials included commercial growers and plant physiologists. The results showed neutral to positive effects on plant growth and fruit production in climates ranging from sunny California to lower light Alberta, Canada. The positive effects on crop production were attributed to the wavelength specific shading of the panels, which enhances the light quality onto the plants.

The company Soliculture was formed in 2012 to commercialize this product. The impact of this project on both building integrated photovoltaics (BIPV), as well as greenhouse growing, is significant. While commercial buildings and skyscrapers have significant surface area that could incorporate BIPV, large-scale commercial greenhouse facilities commonly range in size from 50-100 acres of growing area underneath glass and can greatly increase accessible locations for BIPV, hence creating a substantial subcategory of Greenhouse Integrated Photovoltaics (GIPV).  These growing operations use significant power for pumping, ventilation, refrigeration, and lighting. This technology allows growers to generate power directly above crop production by utilizing their greenhouse structure to support their PV installation. Since the majority of the cost of solar is in the labor and racking system, the integration of the solar panels into the structure is a huge benefit and makes these GIPV panels competitive with conventional PV panels. The result is greener growing with increased profits to growers and enhanced sustainability resulting from a reduced carbon footprint.
